div.head: Section 21
div.p:
But if the aforesaid means (which God forbid) should be omitted, and immediately when Spaniards shall have arrived at those lands and kingdoms and shall have entered them, they should notify the same peoples of such new, so unusual and for ages unheard of by them, indeed not even dreamed of (as we have said) things, namely that they are bound to render obedience, servitude and subjection to a foreign king, and to receive him as universal lord over their own and natural kings and lords, and this as regards all inhabitants, but as regards their kings and princes,
if we speak, if they should hear that they ought to submit their necks to another king's authority and recognize a superior, when they exist as free kings and superior lords and great Lords, ruling magnificently and pompously in their own manner over many other lords: will they not all equally be able to be most fiercely disturbed on hearing these things: terrified and implacably scandalized? Did not King Herod, hearing from the Magi that the King of the Jews was born: become troubled, and all Jerusalem with him? And that they could indeed be disturbed is evident because someone is said to disturb another by simple entry into his possession against his will l. iniuriarum § fine ff de iniuriis and 1 dist c. 1.

¶ Likewise someone disturbs another by taking away fruits
Baldus in l. post sententiam ultima columna C. de sententiis.

¶ Likewise by plowing and gathering of fruits, Baldus in consilium quidam acusatus at the end, and such a disturber is called malicious
Baldus in l. in cunctis, 1 columna C. finium regundo.
¶ Likewise it is called a delict l. si quis § si tutoris. C. si vi aut clam.
Likewise someone is said to disturb by resistance. Baldus in l. 1, C. de testibus.
¶ By selling another's property and handing over possession to the buyer gloss and Bartholus in l. si duo 2 columna ff. uti possidetis.

Likewise by asserting to have a servitude in another's property
gloss and Bartholus in d. l. si duo in princ. 1. q. ff. uti possidetis
and in l. 2 § fine ad finem ff de acqui emptio and in l. menius § fundo ult. colu. ff. de legatis 2.
¶ By disturbing in a servitude of an estate: he is said to disturb in the estate, Bartholus in l. sicut § aristo. verse turbatur § si seruus where the gloss.
¶ Likewise someone disturbs by any annoyance and impediment instit de interdictis § retinendum. Cynus in l. 1, C. uti possidetis

¶ Likewise by denying that the adversary does not possess
Bartholus in l. si prius ff. de operis noui nunciatione.
¶ Likewise when someone asserts himself to possess or to have some right. Baldus in l. ordinari 5 columna C. de rei vendicatione and in l. non ab re. C. vnde vi.

¶ But let us pass over in silence many other examples of disturbance: there is no one who patiently and without greatest disturbance of his spirit
can hear that he should lose his freedom: which thing is known to be inestimable and lovable as was proved above and l. libertas ff. de regulis iuris. And especially that he ought to be subjected to an unknown king, of another unknown race. Since such kings are wont to be little affectionate toward the people over whom they are placed: and consequently do not care much about them. And again to afflict them with exactions, unbearable forced services and to burden them with other unusual burdens. And this was the reason why the Lord prohibited his peculiar people from making themselves a king of another race, as is evident Deuteronomy 17 And St. Thomas 1 2 q. 105 article 1 2. Which also
Bartholus mentions in tractatu de regimine ciuitatis 4 and penultimate columns.

¶ But what I ask will they do and how will they be disturbed, or have been disturbed, those who have suffered so many insults, calamities, and slaughters from our people. And those to whom the Spaniards have not yet come, and nevertheless have heard how many evils we have inflicted on neighboring provinces: when the messengers of our King seek from them their consent and will to receive him as supreme prince. If they probably presume and fear with a fear falling upon the most steadfast men, that they will be despoiled of their goods, dignities and dominions will be taken from them, their wives ravished, they will be orphaned of their children and reduced into complete and most bitter servitude? Truly with the greatest disturbance of their spirits full, with terrible horror and immense pain of the viscera and indignation, they will by no means be able to endure even hearing it.

For who of sound mind will ever dare to doubt that those peoples immediately when they first hear this, will rightly rush to the natural, just and common refuge of all nations. Namely to arms, and will repel force by force with all their might: so that either they expose their life to the dangers of death and finish it in war: or they free their own republics from such invaders whom they judge not undeservedly to be impious and wicked, for they are, and they see themselves most unjustly about to be subjected? What cause is more just for waging war than the repulsion of servitude. According to
Cicero in the Philippics l. 7. And Vegetius de re militari lib. 3 Who doubts that the art of war is more powerful than all things, through which freedom is retained and the dignity of the province is propagated and the empire is preserved. And again, there is no secure possession of riches unless it is preserved by the defense of arms. But concerning these things more fully elsewhere.

Therefore to avoid such grave and unjust disturbance in those peoples: to prevent so many evils which must necessarily intervene in wars, so many deaths, slaughters, devastations of lands (and what is more miserable and lamentable) so many damnations of souls, and consequently so many injustices and most wicked works of tyrants, and so that there may be a just and God-approved entry, principate and universal dominion of our kings into that world: it is necessarily required that most modestly, most gently, most discreetly and most sweetly, with sweet and supplicating words, with good reasons and inducements, they be moved, induced, persuaded to freely give their own consent.

And thus
part 11 of the conclusion concerning which we began to treat in § 16
is evident.
